questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with conductive hearing loss. Imaging reveals a congenital anomaly involving the stapes footplate. Which embryological structure is primarily responsible for the development of the stapes footplate?
Which of the following nerves is primarily responsible for the sensory innervation of the structure marked?

options.label: D
options.text: Auricular branch of the vagus nerve

questions.explanation:
Aspects

Auricle (Pinna)

External Auditory Meatus

Composition

Elastic cartilage, except lobule (fibrofatty tissue)
  • Cartilaginous part (Outer 1/3) with hair and ceruminous glands
  • Bony part (Inner 2/3), with thin skin continuous with the tympanic membrane, lacks hair and glands.

Parts
  • Concha (Depression leading to the external meatus)
  • Helix (Prominent rim with anterior and posterior limbs)
  • Antihelix (Parallel ridge to the helix)
  • Tragus & Antitragus (Separated by inter-tragic notch)
  • Cymba Conchae (Above crus of helix)
  • Lobule (Soft, fleshy part below antitragus)

Nerve Supply

Lateral Surface

  • Lower third: Great auricular nerve (C2, C3)
  • Upper two-thirds: Auriculotemporal nerve (CN V3)
  • Concha: Auricular branch of vagus (CN X) (Alderman’s Nerve)
 

Medial Surface

  • Lower third: Great auricular nerve
  • Upper two-thirds: Lesser occipital nerve (C2)
  • Roof & Anterior Wall: Auriculotemporal nerve (CN V3)
  • Floor & Posterior Wall: Auricular branch of vagus (CN X)

Clinical Relevance

McEwen’s triangle (Cymba Conchae)

  • It is a surgical landmark on the temporal bone to locate the mastoid antrum.

Furuncles (cartilaginous part) susceptible to infections

questions.text: Match the following structures with their respective locations in the middle ear A. Tympanic Plexus 1. Epitympanum B. Head of malleus 2. Lateral wall C. Stapedius muscle 3. Promontory of cochlea D. Tympanic membrane 4. Mesotympanum
questions.explanation:
Boundaries of Middle ear cavity

Roof

(Tegmental Wall)

Formed by the Tegmen tympani, separating the middle ear from the middle cranial fossa.

Floor

(Jugular Wall)
  • A thin bony plate that separates the middle ear from the Internal Jugular Vein.
  • Tympanic canaliculus for the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Anterior Wall (Carotid Wall)
  • Separates the Middle ear from the Internal Carotid Artery
  • Upper part - Tensor Tympani canal.
  • Middle part - Auditory tube opening.
  • Inferior part - Perforated by Sympathetic nerves.

Posterior Wall (Mastoid Wall)
  • Aditus ad antrum: Opening to the mastoid antrum.
  • Fossa incudis: Lodges the short process of the incus.
  • Pyramid: Contains the stapedius muscle.
  • Posterior canaliculus for the chorda tympani nerve.

Lateral Wall (Membranous Wall)

The tympanic membrane, with contributions from the squamous temporal bone.

Medial Wall (Labyrinthine Wall)

Separates the Tympanic cavity from the internal ear

  • Promontory: Projection from the cochlea.
  • Oval Window: Opening for the stapes.
  • Round Window: Covered by the secondary tympanic membrane.
  • Prominence of Lateral Semicircular Canal
  • Tympanic Plexus formed by Glossopharyngeal nerve, is present on the promontory.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with dizziness and balance issues. The physician suspects a problem in the vestibular system. Which of the following structures is primarily responsible for detecting horizontal linear acceleration and head position relative to gravity?
Match the following labelled parts of the nasal septum: 1 a. Septal Cartilage 2 b. Vomer 3 c. Palatine crest 4 d. Perpendicular Plate of Ethmoid
questions.explanation:
Bony Components

Cartilaginous Components
  • Perpendicular Plate of Ethmoid: Forms the posterosuperior part of the septum.
  • Vomer: Makes up the posteroinferior part.
  • Nasal spine of the frontal bone.
  • Crest formed by nasal bones.
  • Sphenoidal crest.
  • Nasal crest from the fusion of the palatine processes of the maxillae and horizontal plates of the palatine bones.
  • Septal Cartilage: Constitutes the major anterior part of the septum, fitting into the angle between the vomer and the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid.
  • Septal Processes of Alar Cartilages: The medial crura of the two major alar cartilages unite at the midline, forming the columella (or columellar septum).
  • Below the columella, a small portion of the septum comprises a double layer of skin without bony or cartilaginous support, known as the membranous septum.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to the ENT clinic with persistent nasal congestion, facial pain, and reduced sense of smell. After minimal relief from medications, a nasal endoscopy is planned. Which of the following openings is not present in the structure labelled “X” in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Site

Location

Openings

Sphenoethmoidal recess

Triangular depression located above and behind the superior concha

Sphenoidal air sinus

Superior meatus

Lies below the superior concha (Smallest).

Posterior ethmoidal air sinuses (Option D)

Middle meatus
  • Lies underneath the middle concha.
  • Has the following parts:
    • Ethmoidal bulla /bulla ethmoidalis (round elevation produced by the underlying middle ethmoidal sinuses).
    • Hiatus semilunaris (semicircular sulcus below the bulla ethmoidalis).
    • Infundibulum (passage at the anterior end of middle meatus).

Bulla ethmoidalis: Middle ethmoidal air sinuses

 

Hiatus semilunaris:

  • Frontal air sinus (Option A)
  • Anterior ethmoidal air sinuses (Option C)
  • Maxillary air sinus (Option B)

Inferior meatus

Lies underneath the inferior nasal concha (Largest).

Nasolacrimal duct (in the anterior part of inferior meatus)

Hasner’s valve guards the opening of the nasolacrimal duct.

questions.text: A 5-month-old child is experiencing excessive tearing in both eyes. The doctor recommends that the parents perform a massage along the nasolacrimal duct (NLD). How should the parents be instructed to carry out this procedure?
questions.explanation:
Nasolacrimal duct

Length

18 mm

Extent

It extends from the lacrimal sac and opens anteriorly into the inferior meatus of the nose.

Orientation

Runs downwards, backwards and laterally (Option A)

Valve

Hasner’s valve: An incomplete mucous fold at the lower end of the duct, preventing air from entering the duct and blowing into the eye when one blows their nose to clear nasal secretions.

Clinical aspect

Epiphora: Excessive secretion of the lacrimal fluid overflowing on the cheeks.

It may occur due to:

  • Hyperlacrimation: Excessive secretion of tears (intake of spicy food or emotional outbreak)
  • Obstruction in lacrimal passages (lacrimal punctum, lacrimal canaliculi, lacrimal sac and nasolacrimal duct)
  • Ectropion (eversion of lower eyelid).

Patency evaluation

Jones dye test 1 & 2 are procedures to assess the patency of the nasolacrimal duct and identify problems related to tear drainage.

questions.text: During retinoscopy, the ophthalmologist inquired of the intern about the development of the eyeball. Could you identify what will develop from the structure labeled "X" in the diagram below?
questions.explanation:
Embryonic Origins of Ocular Structures

Surface ectoderm

Neural plate ectoderm
  • Cornea (1st layer)
  • Eye Lens.
  • Central nervous system
  • Diencephalon
  • Retina
  • Optic nerve
  • Epithelium of ciliary body
  • Epithelium of iris
  • Muscles of the iris (sphincter and dilator muscles)

questions.text: All of the following structures pass through the area labeled "A" in the image except?
questions.explanation:
Superior orbital fissure

Inferior orbital fissure

Divided into three parts by the common tendinous ring of Zinn.

 
  • Within the common tendinous ring:
    • Superior and inferior divisions of the oculomotor (3rd cranial) nerve.
    • Nasociliary nerve
    • Abducent (6th cranial) nerve
    • Sympathetic root of the ciliary ganglion
 
  • Above and lateral to the common tendinous ring:
    • Trochlear (4th cranial) nerve
    • Frontal nerve
    • Lacrimal nerve
    • Lacrimal artery
    • Superior ophthalmic vein
    • Recurrent meningeal branch of the lacrimal artery.
  • Below and medial to the common tendinous ring: Inferior ophthalmic vein
  • Zygomatic nerve (Option A) 
  • Maxillary nerve
  • Branches of the pterygopalatine ganglion (Option C),
  • Infraorbital nerve and vessels (Option B)
  • Vein connecting inferior ophthalmic vein with pterygoid venous plexus.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with difficulty lifting his right eye, describing it as "stuck" when looking upward, along with double vision. Examination reveals a significant limitation in the upward gaze of the right eye. What is the action of the structure labelled "A" in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Voluntary muscles

Involuntary muscles
  • Four recti muscles
    • Superior rectus
    • Inferior rectus
    • Medial rectus
    • Lateral rectus
 
  • Two oblique muscles
    • Superior oblique
    • Inferior oblique
 
  • Levator palpebrae superioris (1)
  • Superior tarsal or Muller's muscle
  • Inferior tarsal
  • Orbitalis.
 

Origin

Insertion

Nerve supply

Recti

Common annular tendon or tendinous ring of Zinn.

(all recti have the same origin)

Sclera little posterior to the limbus (corneoscleral junction)

 

The average distance from Limbus is:

  • Superior: 7.7 mm
  • Inferior: 6.5 mm
  • Medial: 5.5 mm
  • Lateral: 6.9 mm
  
  • Lateral rectus: Abducens nerve
  • Rest all other recti: Oculomotor nerve

Superior oblique

The undersurface of the lesser wing of the sphenoid

Into the sclera behind the equator in the posterior superior quadrant of the eyeball.

Trochlear nerve

Inferior oblique

The orbital surface of the maxilla

Into the sclera behind the equator in the posterior superior quadrant of the eyeball, a little below the superior oblique.

Oculomotor nerve

Levator palpebrae superioris

Orbital surface of the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone.

Superior lamella: Anterior surface of the superior tarsus and skin of the upper eyelid.

Inferior lamella: Upper margin of the superior tarsus and the superior conjunctival fornix.

Superior rectus (SR)

(Option D)

Medial rectus (MR)

Inferior rectus (IR)

Lateral rectus (LR)

Superior oblique (SO)

Inferior oblique (IO)
  • Elevation
  • Adduction
  • Intorsion 
  • Adduction
  • Depression
  • Adduction
  • Extorsion
  • Abduction
  • Depression
  • Abduction
  • Intorsion
  • Elevation
  • Abduction
  • Extorsion

questions.text: Which of the following arteries is not typically injured during mandibular fracture repair?
